Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I glanced at my phone, seeing the text from my sister: “Dinner’s starting, where are you?” My family was gathered just a few yards away, plates already clinking, laughter echoing across the pool deck. I was supposed to be there, sitting with them, catching up and making my mom happy by being present for once. But as I looked up, I caught sight of a group of teenagers at the deep end, daring each other to dive right beneath the bold red “NO DIVING” sign. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind—zero tolerance for rule-breaking, no exceptions, not even for a minute. I felt the weight of my whistle around my neck, the responsibility pressing down on me. My family expected me to be a brother, to join in, to be part of the moment. But the job demanded I act, enforce the rules, keep everyone safe. My heart pounded as I stood between the two worlds, torn by the pull of family and duty, knowing I couldn’t be both at once.
